title: 103_s1225
content:
The Act is titled the "United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act" and authorizes the establishment of a binational commission with Mexico. The President is encouraged to conclude an agreement for this purpose. The United States-Mexico Border Health Commission Act authorizes a commission to conduct a needs assessment in the border area, implement recommended actions, and make recommendations to the governments of both countries. The United States and Mexico are working on a fair method for one country to reimburse the other for healthcare services provided to citizens who cannot afford them. SEC. 4. OTHER AUTHORIZED FUNCTIONS. The Commission is authorized to conduct investigations, research, and studies on health problems in the US-Mexico Border Area, establish a system for gathering health data, and provide assistance to prevent or resolve health issues. The United States section of the Commission consists of 13 members, including the Secretary of Health and Human Services, commissioners of health from border states, and individuals nominated by state executives with expertise in health issues of the US-Mexico Border Area. The Commissioner leads the US section. The Commissioner of the United States section of the Commission, led by the Secretary of Health and Human Services or delegate, receives compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of GS-15 pay and travel expenses for their duties. The Commissioner of the United States section of the Commission, led by the Secretary of Health and Human Services or delegate, receives compensation and travel expenses under subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, while away from their homes or regular places of business in the performance of services. SEC. 6. REGIONAL OFFICES. The Commission may designate border health offices in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California within the US-Mexico Border Area, coordinated with State border health offices and local nonprofit organizations. Offices should avoid duplication and provide compensation for cooperative efforts. The Commission is required to submit an annual report on its activities to the US and Mexican governments each year after its establishment. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS.

The Commission refers to the United States-Mexico Border Health Commission. Health problem includes diseases, ailments, or risks caused by environmental factors. Secretary refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The United States-Mexico Border Area is within 100 kilometers of the border between the two countries.
